questions.text:
At postpartum physical examination, a newborn is found to have male external genitalia. Scrotal examination shows a single palpable testicle in the right hemiscrotum. Ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis shows an undescended left testis, seminal vesicles, uterus, and fallopian tubes. Chromosomal analysis shows a 46, XY karyotype. Which of the following sets of changes is most likely to be found in this newborn?



SRY-gene activity
Müllerian inhibitory factor (MIF)
Testosterone
Dihydrotestosterone (DHT)



A
↓
↓
↓
↓


B
Normal
normal
↑
↑


C
↓
↓
normal
normal


D
Normal
↓
normal
normal


E
Normal
normal
normal
↓
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The combination of decreased SRY-gene activity, MIF, testosterone, and DHT can be seen in Swyer syndrome, in which decreased SRY-gene activity results in nonfunctional gonads and thus no production of testosterone or MIF. Consequently, male genital organs do not develop, and the uterus and vagina develop despite the presence of XY chromosomes.

B) INCORRECT:

The combination of increased testosterone and DHT in the setting of normal SRY-gene activity and MIF can be seen in androgen insensitivity syndrome. Unlike this patient, AIS typically presents with female external genitalia and male internal genitalia.

C) INCORRECT:

The combination of normal testosterone and DHT in the setting of decreased SRY-gene activity and MIF is not possible because normal androgen levels require functioning testes, which need testis-determining factor (TDF) to develop. If the SRY gene is inactive, TDF will also not be synthesized.

D) CORRECT:

The SRY gene on chromosome Y is responsible for encoding the testis-determining factor (TDF) protein, which promotes the development of testis. In the testis, Sertoli cells produce MIF, and Leydig cells secrete testosterone. MIF leads to suppression of paramesonephric ducts, whereas testosterone converts the mesonephric ducts into male internal genitalia (i.e., seminal vesicle, epididymis, ejaculatory duct, ductus deferens). Testosterone is then converted to DHT (via 5α reductase), which is responsible for the development of male external genitalia (from genital tubercle, urethral folds, and genital swelling) and urogenital sinus differentiation (into bulbourethral glands and prostate gland). In the absence of MIF, the paramesonephric duct develops into female internal structures (i.e., fallopian tubes, uterus, upper portion of vagina), as seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Components and derivatives of the undifferentiated gonads, mesonephric ducts, and paramesonephric ducts are labeled blue, yellow, and pink respectively. The undifferentiated gonads develop along the upper pathway in the presence of a functioning SRY gene, resulting in male internal and external genitalia. In the absence of the SRY gene, the lower pathway is followed, resulting in the formation of female internal and external genitalia

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased DHT in the setting of normal (or sometimes increased) testosterone can be seen in 5-alpha-reductase deficiency, which occurs in 46, XY patients who have male internal genitalia but present at birth with female external genitalia. Although male external genitalia can also develop, this first occurs during puberty when the increased synthesis of testosterone leads to virilization (i.e., phallic growth, testicular descent, development of male gender identity).
questions.hint: In the absence of hormones that trigger male sexual development, the default for sexual development is female internal and external genitalia. This newborn has normal male external genitalia and both male and female internal genitalia.

questions.text: A previously healthy 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother 2 hours after the sudden onset of scrotal pain. Physical examination reveals nontender testes and a tender, 5-mm, bluish nodule at the superior pole of the left testis. The patient undergoes urgent surgical exploration of the scrotum. During the operation, the appendix testis is found to be necrotic. In the process of embryologic development, which of the following is mainly involved in the formation of the appendix testis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Leydig cells secrete testosterone, which converts the mesonephric ducts into male internal genitalia (i.e., epididymis, vas deferens, ejaculatory duct, seminal vesicle). Leydig cells are not involved in the development of the appendix testis.
Image Description:

(1) Uniform (sex-independent) embryonic genital (and urinary) structures (before week 8)
(2) Degeneration of the Mullerian ducts and differentiation of the Wolffian ducts
(3) Fully developed male urogenital organs

B) INCORRECT:

Estradiol drives the development of female external genitalia (i.e., clitoris, labia) and further urogenital sinus differentiation (into bladder, urethra, urethral and paraurethral glands, distal vagina, and greater vestibular glands), as well as the development of female secondary sexual characteristics. It has no role in the development of the appendix testis.
Image Description:

(1) Uniform (sex-independent) embryonic genital (and urinary) structures (before week 8)
(2) Degeneration of the Wolffian ducts and differentiation of the Mullerian ducts
(3) Fully developed female urogenital organs

C) INCORRECT:

5-alpha reductase is an enzyme that converts testosterone into dihydrotestosterone, which is responsible for the masculinization of male external genitalia (from genital tubercle, urethral folds, and genital swelling into penis, penile urethra, and scrotum) and further urogenital sinus differentiation (into bladder, urethra, bulbourethral glands, and prostate gland), as well as the development of male secondary sexual characteristics. 5-alpha reductase has no role in the development of the appendix testis.

D) INCORRECT:

Luteinizing hormone stimulates Leydig cells to produce testosterone, which converts the mesonephric ducts into male internal genitalia (i.e., epididymis, vas deferens, ejaculatory duct, seminal vesicle). Testosterone is further converted to dihydrotestosterone, which is then responsible for the development of male external genitalia and further urogenital sinus differentiation. Luteinizing hormone is not involved in the development of the appendix testis.

E) CORRECT:

Sertoli cells produce Müllerian inhibitory factor (MIF), which causes the regression of the paramesonephric duct to the appendix testis. In the absence of MIF, the paramesonephric duct develops into female internal structures (i.e., fallopian tubes, uterus, proximal vagina).
Image Description:

Components and derivatives of the undifferentiated gonads, mesonephric ducts, and paramesonephric ducts are labeled blue, yellow, and pink respectively. The undifferentiated gonads develop along the upper pathway in the presence of a functioning SRY gene, resulting in male internal and external genitalia. In the absence of the SRY gene, the lower pathway is followed, resulting in the formation of female internal and external genitalia
questions.hint: The appendix testis, which is vulnerable to torsion because of its pedunculated shape, is a vestigial remnant of the Müllerian duct system.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician for her annual physical examination. Breast and pubic hair development began at the age of 12 years, but menses have not yet occurred. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 54 kg (120 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. Physical examination shows normal external genitalia. Breast and pubic hair development are Tanner stage 5. A pelvic ultrasound shows normal ovaries but an absent uterus. These findings are most likely due to a defect in which of the following embryologic structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The mesonephric ducts are precursors of the male genital tract (seminal vesicles, epididymis, ejaculatory duct, and ductus deferens) that are testosterone sensitive. In female embryos, insufficient testosterone leads to regression of the ducts into vestigial remnants, including the Gartner ducts. Mesonephric ducts do not participate in uterine development.

B) INCORRECT:

The genital tubercle forms the glans clitoris and vestibular bulbs in females, and the glans penis, corpus cavernosum, and corpus spongiosum in males. This patient presents with normal external genitalia.

C) INCORRECT:

The gubernacula are bands of embryological fibrous tissue that help with the descent of the gonads. In females, they stretch from the ovaries through the inguinal canal into the labia majora. These function to lower the ovaries to their final position in the pelvis and form the round ligament of the uterus. Although it is attached to the uterus, this structure does not participate in uterine formation.

D) INCORRECT:

The urogenital sinus is formed by partitioning the cloaca from the anal canal and gives rise to the lower two-thirds of the vagina including the Bartholin and Skene glands, as well as the bladder and part of the urethra. Defects in this embryonic structure can lead to rectovaginal fistulae, rectovesical fistulae, rectourethral fistulae, and/or a persistent cloaca. The urogenital sinus does not participate in uterine development.

E) CORRECT:

The paramesonephric ducts are precursors of most of the female genital tract, including the fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix, and upper one-third of the vagina. In MRKH syndrome, the ducts do not migrate to their proper anatomic positions in contact with the urogenital sinus, leading to agenesis of the vagina and uterus. While the external genitals appear normal, vaginal inspection usually will reveal a vaginal dimple or blind-ending pouch. A bicornuate uterus occurs when there is only partial fusion of the Müllerian ducts; uterine horn separation would be seen on ultrasound.

As the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis remains unaffected, patients can still experience mittelschmerz pain.
questions.hint: This patient's combination of uterine agenesis, primary amenorrhea, normal ovaries, external genitalia, and secondary sexual characteristics is consistent with Müllerian aplasia, or Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome (MRKH syndrome).

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because she is concerned that her daughter has not started puberty yet. The daughter reports that she is shorter than most of her peers at school and that she has not had her menstrual period. She is at the 15th percentile for height and the 10th percentile for weight. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows absent breast development. Pelvic examination shows normal external female genitalia. There is sparse pubic hair. Serum studies show an elevated FSH and LH and undetectable estradiol. Ultrasonography shows a small uterus, fallopian tubes, and streak ovaries. Chromosomal analysis shows a 46, XY karyotype. A defect in which of the following processes during embryogenesis best explains this patient's condition?

choices.text: Release of testosterone from Leydig cells
Production of androstenedione in adrenal cortex
Release of Mullerian inhibitory factor from Sertoli cells
Expression of testis-determining factor on SRY gene

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The release of testosterone from Leydig cells in the testes during embryogenesis stimulates the differentiation of the mesonephric ducts into male internal genitalia. A defect in this process could explain why this genotypically male patient lacks male internal genitalia and why LH levels are elevated (lack of negative feedback through testosterone). However, Leydig cell dysfunction does not explain the persistence of paramesonephric duct products (female internal genitalia) seen in this patient. Moreover, patients with this condition typically have normal FSH levels because the secretion of inhibin B from Sertoli cells is not affected.

B) INCORRECT:

The enzyme placental aromatase converts androgens to estrogens. In aromatase deficiency, serum testosterone is increased and serum estrogen is decreased. Affected individuals can present with normal internal female genitalia, delayed puberty, primary amenorrhea, and hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, all of which are seen in this patient. However, such individuals have a 46,XX karyotype, are typically born with ambiguous external genitalia, and undergo virilization at the onset of puberty (due to high testosterone levels). In patients with a 46,XY karyotype (like this patient), aromatase deficiency does not affect normal sex development.

C) INCORRECT:

The enzyme 5-alpha-reductase converts testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), which triggers the differentiation of the genital tubercle and urogenital sinus into male external genitalia and the prostate gland during embryogenesis. A defect in this process could explain why this genotypically male patient has no male external genitalia. Patients with 5-alpha-reductase deficiency are born with female or ambiguous external genitalia. However, this condition does not explain the persistence of paramesonephric duct products (female internal genitalia) seen in this patient. Moreover, affected individuals undergo virilization in puberty when testosterone synthesis increases.
Image Description:

Individuals with 5-alpha reductase deficiency are karyotypically male but often grow up with a female gender identity. At birth, external male genitalia and the prostate are underdeveloped because these organs are dependent on dihydrotestosterone for in-utero development. During puberty, testosterone levels increase, resulting in the development of secondary male sexual characteristics, and some individuals undergo a change in gender identity.

D) INCORRECT:

The production of androstenedione in the adrenal cortex provides the precursor hormone for the synthesis of testosterone and estradiol. Disturbed production of androstenedione is seen in 17α-hydroxylase deficiency, a rare form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Like this patient, affected individuals are genotypically male and present with female external genitalia, delayed puberty, primary amenorrhea, and a lack of secondary sex characteristics. However, patients with this deficiency have additional characteristics, including a blind-ending vagina, intraabdominal testes, and hypertension and hypokalemia (due to mineralocorticoid excess), none of which are seen here. Moreover, this patient has sparse pubic hair, which is evidence that androgen production in the adrenal cortex is not defective.

E) INCORRECT:

The release of Mullerian inhibitory factor (MIF) from Sertoli cells suppresses the differentiation of the paramesonephric ducts into female internal genitalia during embryogenesis. A defect in this process is seen in the rare persistent Mullerian duct syndrome. Like this patient, affected individuals have a 46,XY karyotype and female internal genitalia due to decreased MIF levels. However, patients additionally have male external and internal genitalia, which are not seen here.

F) INCORRECT:

The fusion and differentiation of the paramesonephric ducts leads to the development of the female internal genitalia (except ovaries). A defect in this process is seen in Mullerian agenesis (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome), which manifests with primary amenorrhea in patients with female external genitalia. However, unlike this patient, affected individuals typically lack fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix, and parts of the vagina. Furthermore, patients with Mullerian agenesis have a 46,XX karyotype and functioning ovaries, which leads to normal estrogen levels with breast development and normal LH and FSH levels, whereas this patient has a 46,XY karyotype, streak ovaries, and a disturbed hormonal axis.

G) CORRECT:

A defect in the expression of the testis-determining factor (TDF) due to a dysfunctional SRY gene in XY gonadal dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome) prevents the differentiation of the gonads into testes in the 8th week of embryogenesis. In the normal development of a male embryo, the testes produce Mullerian inhibitory factor (by Sertoli cells), testosterone (by Leydig cells), and dihydrotestosterone, which leads to the development of male internal genitalia from the mesonephric ducts and male external genitalia. As seen here, the lack of these substances leads to the development of female internal genitalia from the paramesonephric ducts and female external genitalia.

Instead of functioning gonads, individuals with XY gonadal dysgenesis have streak gonads that do not produce sex hormones. The subsequent estrogen deficiency manifests with primary amenorrhea and delayed puberty (persistently small physique, missing development of secondary sex characteristics). Lifelong estrogen and progestogen substitution enables functional maturation with a regular menstrual cycle.
Image Description:

Components and derivatives of the undifferentiated gonads, mesonephric ducts, and paramesonephric ducts are labeled blue, yellow, and pink respectively. The undifferentiated gonads develop along the upper pathway in the presence of a functioning SRY gene, resulting in male internal and external genitalia. In the absence of the SRY gene, the lower pathway is followed, resulting in the formation of female internal and external genitalia
questions.hint: The presence of streak ovaries and hypergonadotropic hypogonadism in a phenotypically female but genotypically male individual is consistent with XY gonadal dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome).
